review.title: Machine Learning for Machine Data from a CATI Network
review.abstract: This is a machine learning application paper involving big data. We present high-accuracy prediction methods of rare events in semi-structured machine log files, which are produced at high velocity and high volume by NORC's computer-assisted telephone interviewing (CATI) network for conducting surveys. We judiciously apply natural language processing (NLP) techniques and data-mining strategies to train effective learning and prediction models for classifying uncommon error messages in the log---without access to source code, updated documentation or dictionaries. In particular, our simple but effective approach of features preallocation for learning from imbalanced data coupled with naive Bayes classifiers can be conceivably generalized to supervised or semi-supervised learning and prediction methods for other critical events such as cyberattack detection.

metadata.title: Machine Learning for Machine Data from a CATI Network

sections.text: This is a machine learning application paper using big data. We present high-precision prediction methods of rare events in semi-structured machine log files created at high speed and high volume by NORC's computerized telephone interview network (CATI) for conducting surveys. We apply natural language processing (NLP) methods and data mining strategies to train effective learning and prediction models for classifying rare error messages in the protocol - without access to source code, updated documentation or dictionaries. In particular, our simple but effective approach of feature preallocation to learning from unbalanced data in conjunction with naive Bayes classifiers can be applied to supervised or semi-supervised learning and prediction methods for other critical events such as the detection of cyberattacks.Keywords: big data, unbalanced data, rare events, natural language processing, generalized learning.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The data we processed and analyzed in this study comes from NORC's computerized telephone interview system (CATI system), which allows CATI networks to automatically retrieve and select a number of data from a random sample evaluated by a comprehensive list of providers, so that NORC can conduct survey results and collect data on topics of public interest that are representative of a particular population group. Survey results, which traditionally consist of relatively small samples, are often analyzed by statistical techniques (Wolter 2007). More recently, as the size, diversity, and complexity of survey data grow, which are particularly applicable, the results will be applied to knowledge research and predispositive analysis of knowledge. In 2014, as an example, we will use topic models (Blei et al. 2003) to find answers to cluster surveys answered by Wang and Mulrow (2014).

sections.heading: 20140604 103903.913 Error: ProntoEventServer. PE_Client removed on
sections.text: Duration 8453ms Timeout 502ms StackSize 90In our CATI system, however, the message fields are not always standardized, making some messages irregular and more difficult to read than usual by human experts or computer programs. To illustrate such difficulties, we give a few examples below. Example 2.2 Each message field sometimes has missing or additional components. In this example, the timestamp does not contain any annual information and there is an additional slash between the month and the day, followed by a five-digit sequence (02488 below), which is unclear to us what it means:.06 / 04 142452.865 | 02488 | Error | Name | General | onXmlRead > xml element "Alarms" is ignored Example 2.3 In this example, the optional fields appear after - rather than before - the message content. Their order and formats may not necessarily appear in other messages.20140604\ 403402.441 ROCDgDialogD _ 1 = Ungreen dialog.

sections.heading: 20140604 120353.022 CriticalError: Report: SQL Exception: Query: sp_Pronto_AddAgentActivity
sections.text: In other cases, the word "error" is not mentioned anywhere in an error message, or the value of the message type is missing. Here are two examples where the first appears to be an error, while the second is not:

sections.heading: 20140604 144846.946 04776 A:006 line 5 still in dialing mode. Sending error 27 to dial command before ending the session
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 20140604 064238.541 11DE6B80: LineCallSpecificLine(1) return ADVR_NO_ERROR
sections.text: The next example is a message that ends with "no error."

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: We appreciate the contributions and feedback from our colleagues at NORC: Kennon Copeland, Rick Kelly, Matt Krump, Robert Montgomery, Edward Mulrow, Josh Seeger, Benjamin Skalland, Sean Ware, Kirk Wolter, Patrick van Kessel, Patrick Zukosky, as well as members of NORC's Telephone Surveys and Support Operations, Social Media Analytics Group and last but not least the Innovation Days Committee. However, all errors in the paper are our own.

referenceMentions.context: More recently, as sizes, varieties, and complexities of survey data grow faster than ever, novel machine learning methods especially those applicable to text data are sought after for knowledge discovery and predictive analysis at a large scale (see Murphy et al. 2014, for instance), an example being topic models (Blei et al. 2003) applied to cluster survey responses by Wang and Mulrow (2014). Our work here using naive Bayes method to classify machine messages is another attempt in such a direction.

In addition, from machine-generated time stamps, we measured the time lapses between comparable web transactions and log messages; and we learnt about the significant effects of latency (Choi et al. 2014) though we will not go into further details.

Our machine-learning method of choice in this study is naive Bayes classification— it could have been decision tree, random forest, or other models; see, for example, Han et al. (2012) for an overview of these methods.

We can then proceed to compute the prediction model’s accuracy and precision, which are defined as a+d m and a a+b , respectively, as they are among the most common performance measures for a prediction model; see, for example, Han et al. (2012). We use an open-source Python package called Natural Language Toolkit, or NLTK in short; see Bird et al.
We use an open-source Python package called Natural Language Toolkit, or NLTK in short; see Bird et al. (2009). We started with a simple adaptation of the NLTK examples.
We could employ more robust techniques such as k-fold cross validation and ROC curves for model quality evaluation (Han et al. 2012).

metadata.abstractText: This is a machine learning application paper involving big data. We present high-accuracy prediction methods of rare events in semi-structured machine log files, which are produced at high velocity and high volume by NORC’s computer-assisted telephone interviewing (CATI) network for conducting surveys. We judiciously apply natural language processing (NLP) techniques and data-mining strategies to train effective learning and prediction models for classifying uncommon error messages in the log—without access to source code, updated documentation or dictionaries. In particular, our simple but effective approach of features preallocation for learning from imbalanced data coupled with naive Bayes classifiers can be conceivably generalized to supervised or semisupervised learning and prediction methods for other critical events such as cyberattack detection.
